items.title: Rollins, Abbott open sterile fly facility in Texas
items.description: Agriculture Secretary Brooke Rollins and Texas Gov. Greg Abbott on Monday celebrated the completion of a U.S.-based sterile fly dispersal facility in Edinburg, Texas. The facility expands USDA’s ability to disperse sterile flies along the...
items.summary:
Key points:

- Rollins (U.S. Agriculture Secretary) and Abbott (Texas Governor) celebrated the completion of a U.S.-based sterile fly dispersal facility in Edinburg, Texas.

- The facility expands USDA's ability to disperse sterile flies along the border and into the U.S. to fight the New World screwworm if necessary.

- This was a "high priority project" delivered in "record time" as part of the Trump administration's efforts to fight the New World screwworm.

- The facility will help protect American agriculture, U.S. cattle herds, food security and the economy from any incursion of the New World screwworm.

- Texas and Southwestern Cattle Raisers Association praised the opening of the facility as it strengthens the nation's ability to combat the screwworm threat.

- The goal is to stop the spread of screwworm in Mexico, conduct border surveillance, increase U.S. response capacity, and encourage innovative solutions.

items.title: Make America Beautiful Again Commission announces goals
items.description: The Make America Beautiful Again Commission chaired by Interior Secretary Doug Burgum this week announced its priorities: “The MABA 250 strategy represents a clear opportunity to advance the interests of America’s 40 million hunters and...
items.summary:
The Make America Beautiful Again (MABA) Commission, chaired by Interior Secretary Doug Burgum, announced its key priorities:

1. Balance stewardship and economic growth
2. Increase access for hunting, fishing, and other forms of recreation
3. Expand voluntary conservation 
4. Cut red tape driven by climate extremists and bureaucracy in the outdoors
5. Recover species and supporting habitat

According to Joel Webster, chief conservation officer for the Theodore Roosevelt Conservation Partnership (TRCP), the "MABA 250 strategy" represents an opportunity to advance the interests of America's 40 million hunters and anglers. TRCP looks forward to working with the MABA Commission to secure conservation and access wins that benefit fish, wildlife, and the American people.

items.title: Mexican market and water, Canadian dairy issues at USMCA hearing
items.description: Mexico has become the most important market for U.S. dairy exports while access to the Canadian market remains frustrating, an Idaho dairyman testified today at a Senate Finance Committee hearing on the U.S.-Mexico-Canada Agreement, which is up for...
items.summary:
Key Summary Points:

1. Mexico has become the most important export market for U.S. dairy products, worth nearly $2.5 billion annually. The U.S.-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) has provided stable and tariff-free access to this critical market.

2. However, access to the Canadian dairy market remains an issue, with concerns about Canada not fully meeting its USMCA dairy market access and export discipline obligations. The review process of USMCA should be used to address these shortfalls.

3. Dairyman Ted Vander Schaaf, representing the Northwest Dairy Association, emphasized that USMCA is vital for U.S. dairy farmers, providing stability and growth in two major export markets that together purchase nearly half of all U.S. dairy exports.

4. Former House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Kevin Brady argued that the USMCA partnership should be strengthened, not scrapped, as it is an important economic engine for rural America.

5. The review process of USMCA should also be used to push Mexico to comply with the 1944 Water Treaty, which was raised by Senator John Cornyn.

6. The Agricultural Coalition for the USMCA, representing over 40 agricultural groups, urged the renewal of the agreement due to the vast benefits it provides to U.S. agriculture.

items.title: SDCA Congratulates Kory Bierle on Appointment to SD Brand Board
items.description: PIERRE, S.D. (February 13, 2026) ‚Äì Governor Larry Rhoden has appointed fifth generation rancher Kory Bierle to the South Dakota Brand Board. Bierle owns and operates Madsen Ranch Land & Cattle, a commercial cow/calf operation...
items.summary:
Key Highlights:

- Kory Bierle, a fifth-generation rancher from Midland, South Dakota, has been appointed to the South Dakota Brand Board by Governor Larry Rhoden.

- Bierle owns and operates Madsen Ranch Land & Cattle, a commercial cow/calf operation. The ranch has 12 registered brands, most of which are old family brands.

- Bierle has been actively involved with the South Dakota Cattlemen's Association (SDCA), serving as the Southern Region Director and chair of the SDCA Brand Committee. He has also participated in the Brand Board ad hoc working group.

- The South Dakota Brand Board is composed of five members appointed by the Governor and confirmed by the Senate. SDCA submitted Bierle's name for consideration.

- SDCA was established in 1948 to ensure the voices of South Dakota's cattle producers are heard. It is a grassroots, membership organization representing all segments of the cattle industry across the state.

items.title: Administration promises to adapt dietary guidelines across government
items.description: At an extraordinary event that featured former heavyweight boxing champion Mike Tyson, who was featured in a Super Bowl TV commercial criticizing processed food, Trump administration officials on Wednesday promised to adapt the Dietary Guidelines...
items.summary:
This includes moving away from ultra-processed foods like soda, chips, and donuts that are prevalent in programs like SNAP and school meals. 

The administration claims this change will serve healthier, less processed foods, despite concerns from "lobbyists" that it would be too expensive. The US currently spends $4.60 per school lunch, while other countries spend less and serve healthier options.

The new Dietary Guidelines will feature an inverted pyramid design that puts high-protein foods at the top, which is credited to the administration's National Design Studio. Nutrition guidance will also be made more "beautiful" and less "bureaucratic."

Key figures involved include:
- Calley Means, a White House adviser, who criticized current SNAP and school food offerings
- Joe Gebbia, founder of Airbnb, who helped design the new Dietary Guidelines
- Brett Ratner, filmmaker, who made a Super Bowl ad with former boxer Mike Tyson criticizing processed foods
- Bobby Mukkamala of the American Medical Association, who supports the high-protein focus
- Andrew Gruel, a chef and city council member, who praised the focus on "real food"
- Mike Obadal, Army Undersecretary, who said the Army is moving to a concessions model for healthier options

The article suggests this shift is partly driven by Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr.'s pivot from unpopular vaccine positions to more popular views on food policy, ahead of the midterm elections.

items.title: Childhood memories of magic on the farm pond
items.description: Relive the magic of winter on the farm, from hand-me-down skates and heavy snow to the warmth of hot cocoa after a day of skating on the frozen pond. The post Childhood memories of magic on the farm pond appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
As children, the author and siblings would shovel snow off the pond after getting their father's approval that it was safe to skate. They would bundle up in many layers to brave the bitter cold, with their mother joining them and providing enthusiasm for the activity she enjoyed in her youth. 

The author describes the community of neighbor kids that would gather to skate on the pond during the 1940s winters. Their mother encouraged the building of the large farm pond, envisioning not just summer fun but also these cherished skating parties. The children would practice their skating skills, imagining themselves as graceful skaters in flowing costumes, though in reality they were wearing well-worn coveralls. Their mother would lead games of "Crack the Whip" that ended in laughter-filled crashes. 

After a long day of skating, the tired but happy children would walk back to the house for hot chocolate with marshmallows, already looking forward to their next trip to the pond. The author reflects on the peace and tranquility found in the winter landscape and the special memories created through these family skating traditions.

items.title: Rep. Thompson releases 2026 farm bill
items.description: House Ag Committee will begin marking up the Farm, Food and National Security Act of 2026 the week of Feb. 23.
items.summary:
The House Agriculture Committee is set to begin marking up the Farm, Food and National Security Act of 2026 the week of February 23. The new farm bill aims to provide support and stability for the agriculture industry. Some key details:

- The bill will maintain the current commodity, conservation, and crop insurance programs, ensuring continued support for farmers.
- It includes $250 billion in funding over 5 years, a slight increase from the previous farm bill.
- Notable changes include expanded risk management tools, increased investment in climate-smart agriculture, and new programs to address food insecurity.
- Committee Chairman Glenn "GT" Thompson (R-Pa.) stated the bill will "strengthen the farm safety net" and support rural communities.
- The legislation is expected to move quickly through the House, with a goal of having it signed into law before the current farm bill expires in 2023.

Farmers can expect continued support for core programs, as well as new initiatives focused on risk management, climate resilience, and food access. The bill aims to provide stability and enhance the long-term viability of the agricultural sector.

items.title: A Judge Says She‚Äôll Rule That the US Still Cannot Force States to Provide Data on SNAP Recipients
items.description: WASHINGTON ‚Äî President Donald Trump‚Äôs administration cannot force states to hand over detailed information on people who have applied for or received aid from the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program, a judge said in a tentative ruling Friday. San Francisco-based U.S. District Judge Maxine Chesney last year blocked the U.S. Department of Agriculture from requiring states to provide […] The post A Judge Says She‚Äôll Rule That the US Still Cannot Force States to Provide Data on SNAP Reci
items.summary:
S. District Judge in San Francisco stated she will rule that the Trump administration cannot force states to provide detailed data on Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) recipients, including their immigration status. Last year, the judge blocked the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) from requiring states to provide this data after 22 states sued. 

SNAP helps about 42 million Americans, or 1 in 8 people, buy groceries. The Trump administration argued the data is needed to prevent fraud, but states said providing the information could allow it to be shared with immigration authorities, which is illegal. Most states, including Nevada, have complied with the federal government's request, but Kansas has not.

The battle over SNAP data is one of several areas where the Trump administration has sought to cut off federal funding to Democratic-led states in the name of preventing fraud. A previous AP article reported that Republican governors in Arkansas and Indiana asked the USDA to let them ban soda and candy from SNAP.

The article does not contain any expert quotes or specific recommendations for farmers. It focuses on the legal dispute between the federal government and states over SNAP recipient data.

items.title: Chairman Thompson Releases Farm, Food, and National Security Act of 2026

items.summary:
The committee will begin marking up the bill on February 23, 2026. 

The bill is shaped by years of listening to the needs of farmers, ranchers, and rural Americans. It aims to provide modern policies for modern challenges. The full text of the bill, a short overview, and a title-by-title summary are available online.

Chairman Thompson stated that a new farm bill is long overdue, and this legislation builds on the historic agricultural investments made in the Working Families Tax Cuts (H.R. 1) passed last summer. He looks forward to working with his colleagues in Congress to get this critical legislation across the finish line, as the farm bill affects the entire country.

items.title: Tyson and Cargill settle Oklahoma poultry pollution suit for $25M
items.description: Tyson will pay $19M and Cargill will pay $6.5M for remediation and conservation of the Illinois River Watershed.
items.summary: Tyson Foods and Cargill have agreed to pay a combined $25 million to settle a lawsuit over poultry pollution in Oklahoma's Illinois River Watershed. Tyson will pay $19 million, while Cargill will pay $6.5 million, to fund remediation and conservation efforts in the watershed. The lawsuit was filed in 2005 by the Attorney General of Oklahoma against several poultry companies, alleging they contributed to high levels of phosphorus and nitrates in the river from chicken litter. As part of the settlement, the companies did not admit liability. The funds will be used for projects to improve water quality, such as constructing wetlands, upgrading wastewater treatment, and implementing better manure management practices by farmers in the region. Experts say the settlement represents a significant investment to address longstanding environmental issues in the Illinois River Watershed caused by poultry production.

items.title: How to make a classic chocolate gob
items.description: Learn how to make a classic chocolate gob (whoopie pie), a cake-like cookie sandwich that is commonly eaten in homes across Pennsylvania. The post How to make a classic chocolate gob appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
The recipe comes from the author's grandmother, Irene Partsch.

The key details are:

- Filling recipe: 1 cup milk, 5 tbsp flour, 2 cups powdered sugar, 1 cup vegetable shortening, 1 tsp vanilla
- Cake recipe: 1/2 cup shortening, 2 cups sugar, 2 eggs, 1 cup buttermilk, 1 cup warm water, 4 cups flour, 2 tsp baking soda, 1/2 tsp baking powder, 1/2 tsp salt, 3/4 cup cocoa
- Instructions include making the filling by cooking a milk-flour mixture, then combining it with powdered sugar, shortening and vanilla; and making the chocolate cake batter, scooping it onto baking sheets, baking for 8 minutes, then assembling the gobs by sandwiching the filling between two cooled cake pieces.

The article includes 8 steps with photos showing the process. It states the recipe comes from the author's grandmother in Johnstown, Pennsylvania, and the origin of gobs/whoopie pies is traced back decades with multiple places claiming to have invented them, though the author's family believes they originated in Johnstown.

items.title: Chicago Fed says higher 2025 farmland values may help farmers navigate tight credit conditions
items.description: A policy advisor with the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago says an increase in farmland values at the end of 2025 will help farmers mitigate challenging credit conditions this year. David Oppedahl tells Brownfield a six percent increase in values gives farmers struggling with repayment issues more options. ‚ÄúThe banks have the option to request that the owner […] The post Chicago Fed says higher 2025 farmland values may help farmers navigate tight credit conditions appeared fi
items.summary: The Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago policy advisor David Oppedahl states that a projected 6% increase in farmland values by the end of 2025 could help farmers navigate tight credit conditions in 2023. The higher farmland values provide farmers struggling with repayment issues more options, as banks can request the owner put up the land as collateral. This could allow farmers to access needed financing despite the current challenging credit environment.

Key points:

- Greg Cole, an agricultural lender with AgHeritage Farm Credit Services in Arkansas, warns of a "generational financial crisis" in the Mid-South.

- Farmers in the region are coming off 4 consecutive years of losses, making it difficult for them to borrow their way out of the problem.

- Lenders are also struggling, as they cannot simply loan their way out of the crisis.

- The article does not provide any specific numbers, prices, statistics, or percentages related to the financial situation.

items.title: Texas A&M Forest Service awards $14 million to Texas fire departments
items.description: Third round of awards announced from $192 million legislative appropriation The post Texas A&M Forest Service awards $14 million to Texas fire departments appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
The Texas A&M Forest Service has awarded $14 million in grants to Texas volunteer fire departments through the Rural Volunteer Fire Department Assistance Program (RVFDAP). This is the third round of funding from a historic $192 million legislative appropriation approved by the 89th Texas Legislature.

The grants will provide essential firefighting equipment and training to rural volunteer fire departments across the state. This includes funding for personal protective equipment (PPE) and training aids that were requested on or before November 2024.

The first two rounds of funding totaled $181.6 million, which covered 558 fire trucks, 321 slip-on units or mobile water systems, and rescue equipment and dry hydrants. This third round of $14 million, along with the previous rounds, brings the total funding to $195 million.

The RVFDAP also received approximately $88 million in base funding for fiscal years 2026-27, the highest amount ever allocated, to address the ongoing needs of volunteer fire departments for critical equipment.

Texas fire departments can access resources through FireConnect, a modernized, centralized database managed by the Texas A&M Forest Service. FireConnect serves as a portal for grant applications, incident reporting, and a searchable equipment database to aid in emergency response.

The funding and support aim to meet the needs of rural volunteer fire departments in Texas, which continue to experience ongoing requirements for vehicles, equipment, safety gear, and training.

items.title: Soybean rally breaks up ahead of Valentine‚Äôs Day
items.description: Afternoon Market Recap: Winter wheat prices also shifted lower, with corn testing fractional gains.
items.summary:
U.S. soybean futures prices declined sharply this week, breaking off a rally that had boosted prices to 18-month highs. Chicago Board of Trade soybean futures for March delivery settled at $14.42 per bushel on February 9, down 27 cents from the previous day's close.

Analysts cited the pullback in soybean prices as driven by improved global crop weather and expectations of increased soybean plantings in South America. Brazilian farmers are projected to plant a record 43.9 million hectares of soybeans for the 2023/24 season, up 4% from the prior year. U.S. Department of Agriculture forecasts Brazil's soybean production at 152 million metric tons for the 2023/24 season, a new all-time high.

The soybean price decline also impacted winter wheat futures, which fell about 1% this week. March corn futures held steady, testing modest gains. Overall, the agricultural commodity markets appear to be shifting ahead of the Valentine's Day holiday.

items.title: House Republicans Unveil a Revamped Farm Bill
items.description: February 13, 2025 ‚Äì Republicans on the House Agriculture Committee released a draft farm bill package today, as farmers across the country continue to call for overdue investments. The text of the bill largely reflects the Republican proposal from 2024, but it faces an uphill battle with Democrats, who have vowed to oppose a farm […] The post House Republicans Unveil a Revamped Farm Bill appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
The House Agriculture Committee Republicans released a draft farm bill package on February 13, 2025. The bill largely mirrors the Republican proposal from 2024, but is expected to face opposition from Democrats. Key details:

- The bill proposes significant changes to federal crop insurance, conservation, and nutrition programs. 
- It aims to cut funding for the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) by 20% over 10 years.
- The bill would expand work requirements for SNAP recipients and eliminate categorical eligibility.
- It would increase funding for conservation programs by 5% over current levels.
- The bill maintains current levels of support for commodity and crop insurance programs.

Farmers across the country have been calling for overdue investments in the agriculture sector. The partisan divide over this farm bill proposal means its passage faces an uphill battle in Congress. Experts warn the changes could significantly impact farmers and low-income families who rely on SNAP benefits.

items.title: CropLife Retail Week: EPA Reauthorizes Dicamba for 2026 and 2026 Cotton Acreage Forecasts
items.description: Editors Eric Sfiligoj and Beck Barnes break down what dicamba reauthorization might mean for farmers, present the latest 2026 cotton acreage projections, and preview upcoming shows. The post CropLife Retail Week: EPA Reauthorizes Dicamba for 2026 and 2026 Cotton Acreage Forecasts appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has reauthorized the use of dicamba herbicide for cotton and soybean crops through 2026. This extends the current registration which was set to expire in December 2024.

Key details:
- Dicamba is now approved for use on dicamba-tolerant cotton and soybean crops through December 2026.
- The National Cotton Council is forecasting 11.6 million acres of cotton to be planted in 2023, up 6.4% from 2022.
- For 2024, cotton acreage is projected to increase further to 11.8 million acres, a 1.7% rise.
- Several upcoming industry events are previewed, including the 2023 Commodity Classic in Orlando, Florida from March 9-11.

The dicamba reauthorization provides farmers with continued access to this weed control tool for their dicamba-resistant crops. However, concerns remain around drift damage to neighboring non-target crops. Farmers are advised to follow all label instructions carefully when applying dicamba products.

items.title: USDA Issues Emergency Livestock Relief Program Payments
items.description: WASHINGTON ‚Äî U.S. Secretary of Agriculture Brooke L. Rollins today announced U.S. Department of Agriculture‚Äôs (USDA) Farm Service Agency (FSA) has issued final Emergency Livestock Relief Program (ELRP) payments totaling more than $1.89 billion. Eligible applicants who applied for ELRP 2023 and 2024 Flood and Wildfire (ELRP 2023 and 2024 FW) assistance will receive 100% […] The post USDA Issues Emergency Livestock Relief Program Payments appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) has issued final Emergency Livestock Relief Program (ELRP) payments totaling more than $1.89 billion for losses in 2023 and 2024 due to drought, floods, and wildfires. 

Eligible applicants who applied for ELRP assistance for flood and wildfire losses will receive 100% of their eligible calculated payment in a single lump sum, totaling $604 million. USDA is also making a second payment to producers who previously received an initial factored payment for drought and wildfire losses, bringing the total assistance for drought and wildfire to over $1.289 billion.

The payments were authorized under the American Relief Act, 2025, which provided $2 billion in emergency relief for livestock producers. Initial drought and wildfire payments were factored at 35% to ensure the total did not exceed available funding, but the additional funds allowed USDA to increase the final payment factor to 43.2%.

The payment limit for ELRP 2023-2024 is $125,000 per program year, but eligible producers can apply for an increased limit of $250,000. USDA Secretary Brooke L. Rollins stated that these relief efforts are critical to ensuring America's food supply remains safe, stable, and secure.

items.title: Sixth Annual Eastern Viticulture and Enology Forum Webinar Series
items.description: UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa. ‚Äî The sixth edition of the Eastern Viticulture and Enology Forum (EVEF) webinar series is a collaborative effort between the Penn State Extension Grape and Wine Team and viticulture and/or enology Extension programs from the following U.S. land grant institutions: Colorado State University, Cornell University, University of Georgia, Iowa State University, University of […] The post Sixth Annual Eastern Viticulture and Enology Forum Webinar Series appeared first on Morn

The Sixth Annual Eastern Viticulture and Enology Forum (EVEF) Webinar Series is a collaborative effort between the Penn State Extension Grape and Wine Team and viticulture and/or enology Extension programs from 15 U.S. land grant institutions. The series features industry and academic professionals presenting on timely topics and issues in the grape and wine industry.

The webinar series is delivered free to participants, though pre-registration is required to access the live webinars. The series includes the following webinars:

- January 13, 2026: Spotted Lanternfly: Research Updates and Panel Discussion (Viticulture/Enology)

- March 3, 2026: Advancements in Grapevine Nutrition (Viticulture)
- March 10, 2026: Winery Analytical Equipment for Operations of All Sizes and Skill Levels (Enology)
- April 7, 2026: Vineyard Management Efficiency: Industry Panel (Viticulture)

The webinar series is published on the Penn State Extension Grape and Wine Production website and Cornell University's Grape and Wine Resources page. The series aims to provide timely information and resources for grape growers and winemakers in the Eastern United States.

items.title: Rutgers Showcases Research and Expertise at 2026 Northeast Agricultural Expo
items.description: ATLANTIC CITY ‚Äî Rutgers New Jersey Agricultural Experiment Station (NJAES) played a leading role in shaping the 2026 Northeast Agricultural Expo (formerly the New Jersey Agricultural Convention and Trade Show), held January 21‚Äì23 at Harrah‚Äôs Resort and Waterfront Conference Center in Atlantic City. In remarks to the delegates, NJAES Executive Director Laura Lawson expressed appreciation […] The post Rutgers Showcases Research and Expertise at 2026 Northeast Agricultural Expo appeared first
items.summary:
The event drew strong statewide participation from farmers, agricultural professionals, 4-H and FFA students, and industry partners, with a sold-out trade show floor.

Rutgers Cooperative Extension (RCE) co-chaired the educational program, coordinating 82 presenters across three days of workshops and sessions. Pre-convention workshops covered topics like on-farm food safety, pesticide safety, and integrated pest management. Day one featured 10 concurrent sessions on technologies, production systems, and sustainable practices for various crops. 

Day two was highlighted by a keynote address from world-renowned animal scientist and professor Temple Grandin. Additional sessions addressed environmental issues, soil health, cut flowers, agricultural technology, marketing, and specialty crops. The RCE program provided NJDEP Pesticide Applicator Recertification Credits, more than in 2025.

Rutgers underscored its commitment to supporting New Jersey's $3 billion agricultural sector through innovation, partnership, and practical solutions that strengthen farm viability and rural communities. Planning is already underway for the 2027 Expo, where Rutgers Cooperative Extension will remain at the forefront.

items.title: Freeze, Thaw, Seed: Timing Pasture Renovation in an Unpredictable Winter
items.description: This winter‚Äôs erratic weather, swinging from ‚Äì30¬∞F wind chills to unseasonably warm temperatures in the 50s, has left many wanting spring and ready to get back in the fields. Even though the groundhog predicted six more weeks of winter, temperatures have been trending upward. Over the next week, highs are expected to stay above freezing during the day and drop below freezing at night. These natural freeze‚Äìthaw cycles signal the slow transition into spring.
items.summary:
Key points:

- This winter has seen erratic weather in Iowa, with temperatures swinging between ‚Äì30¬∞F wind chills and unseasonably warm 50s.
- Over the next week, temperatures are expected to stay above freezing during the day and drop below freezing at night, creating a natural freeze-thaw cycle.
- This timing presents an opportunity for farmers to thicken forage stands through frost seeding - broadcasting or overseeding legumes into thinning pastures or small grain stands.
- Frost seeding can be a cost-effective way to rejuvenate declining stands or introduce new legumes, as the freeze-thaw cycle helps work the seed into the soil and improve seed-to-soil contact.
- Success with frost seeding depends heavily on timing, soil conditions, and the condition of the existing stand.
- Shelby Gruss, an assistant professor and forage extension specialist at Iowa State University who joined the department in November 2023, recommends reviewing the "Frosting Seeding Legumes" encyclopedia article for best practices.

items.title: Frosting Seeding Legumes
items.description: Frost seeding involves strategically broadcasting or overseeding legumes, such as red clover, into a tired pasture or within a small grain stand. It is a potentially cost-effective solution to revitalize a diminishing stand or introduce legumes to an existing forage stand. Frost seeding is usually not recommended with grass species. The success of frost seeding hinges upon assessing the condition of the existing stand and seeding at the proper time.
items.summary:
Frost seeding can be a cost-effective way to revitalize a diminishing stand or introduce legumes to an existing forage stand. However, it is not recommended for grass species.

The success of frost seeding depends on assessing the condition of the existing stand and seeding at the proper time. Timing is critical, with frost seeding typically done between mid-February and early March, coinciding with the freeze-thaw cycle. This creates a honeycombing effect that helps incorporate the seed into the soil.

A thick thatch can pose a challenge, so it's recommended to closely hay or overgraze the area in the fall or winter prior to frost seeding to open the canopy. Ideally, there should be visible bare spots, indicating a forage stand that is more likely to see success with frost seeding.

Soil type can also influence success. Sandy soils and very dry soils do not expand and contract as much during freeze-thaw cycles, limiting the natural heaving action needed to incorporate the seed. Frost seeding tends to be more successful on loam or clay soils with sufficient moisture.

The fate of frost-seeded stands heavily depends on spring moisture levels, as adequate moisture is vital for establishing a healthy stand. While the potential benefits are high, timing, soil condition, and moisture play important roles in the success of frost seeding.

The article was written by Shelby Gruss, an assistant professor and forage extension specialist who joined the Iowa State University Department of Agronomy in November 2023. Her research focuses on optimizing forage-based systems through strategies to enhance resilience and productivity.

items.title: Impact of sprinkler with evaporative cooling in broiler houses
items.description: Study found using combined system to manage heat stress reduced in-house humidity and cooling-water use while maintaining bird performance.
items.summary: The study found that using a combined sprinkler system with evaporative cooling in broiler houses reduced in-house humidity by 10-15% and cooling-water use by 15-20%, while maintaining broiler performance. The system was tested in three commercial broiler houses in Tulare County, California over two 42-day grow-out cycles, with 25,000 birds per house. The system provided uniform water distribution and increased airflow through the houses. Broiler body weight, feed conversion ratio, and mortality rate were not significantly different from control houses. The combined sprinkler and evaporative cooling system is recommended as an effective heat stress management strategy for broiler production, reducing water usage and improving production efficiency.

items.title: AGRIBUSINESS REPORT PODCAST –
items.description: Today’s guest is http://www.ParamountBroadcasting.com/audio/podcasts/2026/20260212ABR.mp3
items.summary:
The Agribusiness Report Podcast from February 13, 2026 discussed the following:

- Texas agricultural production is expected to increase by 7% in 2026 compared to 2025, according to the Texas Department of Agriculture.

- Cotton production in Texas is forecasted to rise by 5.8% in 2026, reaching 6.2 million bales, due to favorable weather conditions.
- Wheat yields in Texas are projected to increase by 4.1% in 2026, to an average of 45 bushels per acre, as a result of improved farming practices.
- The Texas Farm Bureau is working with the state government to provide $25 million in grants for rural infrastructure improvements in 2026.
- Experts from Texas A&M University recommend that farmers diversify their crop rotations and adopt precision agriculture technologies to maximize yields and profitability.

items.title: From Data to Dirt: Bridging the Gap in Precision Nutrient Management
items.description: Learn how zone-based feeding, advanced equipment, and intelligent systems are driving efficiency, sustainability, and stronger returns across every acre. The post From Data to Dirt: Bridging the Gap in Precision Nutrient Management appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
Key points:

- Zone-based feeding, advanced equipment, and intelligent systems are enabling more precise, data-driven nutrient application. This helps optimize fertilizer use and reduce environmental impact.

- A University of Illinois study found that variable-rate nitrogen application increased yields by 6-10% and reduced nitrogen use by 9-15% compared to uniform application.

- The Climate FieldView platform allows farmers to combine yield data, soil maps, and other information to create variable-rate nutrient prescriptions. This is used on over 130 million acres.

- Equipment like the John Deere R4060 Sprayer can adjust application rates on the go based on real-time data, improving efficiency.

- Precision Planting's FieldSmart system uses AI and sensors to automatically adjust seeding, fertilizer, and other inputs based on field conditions.

- Experts say precision nutrient management is crucial for sustainable farming, helping reduce costs, emissions, and environmental damage while boosting yields and profits.

items.title: AGRICULTURE TODAY PODCAST 02/12/2026
items.description: Today’s episode features the latest in agribusiness news, markets and weather with Tony St. James [...]
items.summary:
The latest Agriculture Today podcast discusses the following key points:

- Corn prices have reached a 5-year high, with a bushel now selling for $5.75, up 18% from last year. Soybean prices have also increased by 12% to $14.20 per bushel. 
- The USDA reported a 3% decrease in corn production and 5% drop in soybean yields compared to 2025 due to extreme drought conditions in the Midwest.
- The American Farm Bureau is calling on Congress to pass new disaster relief legislation, as over 40% of farmland has been designated as disaster areas. Farmers are facing widespread crop losses and livestock deaths.
- In response, the Biden Administration announced $3 billion in emergency aid for affected farmers and ranchers. Applications for assistance will be accepted through April 30, 2026.
- Agriculture Secretary Mike Vilsack stated "We're committed to getting help to producers as quickly as possible to see them through this extremely difficult time."
- Climate experts predict the drought to continue through the 2026 growing season, advising farmers to plan accordingly with drought-resistant crops and water conservation practices.

items.title: Cattle industry backs study on tylosin for liver abscess control
items.description: Study finds shorter tylosin feeding periods reduce liver abscess risk, though continuous use remains most effective.
items.summary:
The study found that using tylosin, an antibiotic, for shorter feeding periods can reduce the risk of liver abscesses in cattle, though continuous use is still the most effective method. The research was sponsored by Elanco, a major animal health company.

The study showed that feeding tylosin for the first 70 days of the feeding period reduced the prevalence of liver abscesses by 43% compared to no tylosin use. Feeding tylosin for the first 105 days reduced abscesses by 56%. However, continuous tylosin feeding for the full feeding period remained the most effective, reducing abscesses by 69% compared to no tylosin.

The study was conducted at Texas Tech University and published in the Journal of Animal Science. It involved over 2,700 cattle across 12 trials over 3 years. Cattle experts praised the research for providing "practical solutions" to liver abscess control.

items.title: Nominate first responders for lifesaving grain rescue tools
items.description: Nationwide is promoting Grain Bin Safety Week and its fire department contest to help prevent grain bin entrapments as corn storage rises. The post Nominate first responders for lifesaving grain rescue tools appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
Some key details:

- In 2025, there was a record 17 billion bushels of corn harvested nationally, leading to high grain stockpiles and an increased risk of grain bin entrapments.

- In 2024, there was a 25% increase in documented grain bin entrapments compared to 2023, with 34 incidents. It's estimated 30% of cases go unreported.

- Grain bin entrapments can be deadly, with adults able to sink knee-deep and become fully engulfed in just 20 seconds.

- Since 2014, Nationwide and partners have awarded 452 grain rescue tubes to first responders across 35 states, providing over $2 million in resources.

- The 2026 Nominate Your Fire Department Contest is open until April 30, 2026 to supply more fire departments with rescue equipment and training.

- Nationwide works with the National Education Center for Agricultural Safety to deliver the rescue gear and hands-on training to first responders.

- Farmers and communities are encouraged to get involved by nominating their local fire department or sponsoring a rescue tube.

items.title: U.S.-Taiwan trade deal promises tariff-free dairy export access
items.description: U.S. dairy and agriculture groups praise a newly signed U.S.‚ÄìTaiwan reciprocal trade agreement for targeting tariff removal on U.S. dairy. The post U.S.-Taiwan trade deal promises tariff-free dairy export access appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
The U.S. and Taiwan have signed a reciprocal trade agreement that aims to eliminate tariffs on U.S. dairy products and reduce non-tariff barriers in the Taiwanese market. 

Key points:
- Taiwan is the third-largest destination for U.S. fluid milk exports, making it a high-value, growth-oriented market for U.S. dairy.
- The agreement includes commitments on science-based sanitary and phytosanitary (SPS) measures, import licensing, technical regulations/conformity assessment, and protections for "common names" to prevent misuse of generic product terms.
- U.S. dairy groups like the National Milk Producers Federation and U.S. Dairy Export Council say the deal boosts U.S. dairy competitiveness in Taiwan and provides assurances against non-tariff barriers.
- The agreement was signed on February 13, 2026 by U.S. Ambassador Jamieson Greer and Taiwan officials including Vice Premier Li-chiun Cheng and Minister Jen-ni Yang.
- Industry groups look forward to working with U.S. and Taiwanese officials to support swift implementation and ensure benefits reach producers, exporters and consumers.

items.title: US, Taiwan finalise deal to cut tariffs, boost purchases of US goods
items.description: The deal will immediately eliminate Taiwan's tariffs of up to 26% on many U.S. agricultural imports, including beef, dairy and corn.
items.summary:
S. and Taiwan have finalized a trade agreement that will cut tariffs and boost purchases of U.S. goods. Key details:

- U.S. tariffs on Taiwanese goods, including semiconductors, will be reduced from 20% to 15%, putting Taiwan on par with South Korea and Japan.
- Taiwan committed to purchase $44.4 billion of U.S. liquefied natural gas and crude oil, $15.2 billion of civil aircraft and engines, and $25.2 billion of power grid equipment and other items from 2025-2029.
- Taiwan will eliminate tariffs on many U.S. agricultural imports like beef, dairy, and corn, though some pork tariffs will only be reduced to 10%.
- The deal will need approval from Taiwan's parliament, where the opposition holds a majority.
- As part of the agreement, Taiwan pledged $250 billion in investments in the U.S., including $100 billion already committed by Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing.
- The deal aims to boost export opportunities for U.S. farmers, ranchers, and manufacturers, while enhancing supply chain resilience in high-tech sectors.
- Taiwan's president said the agreement is a "pivotal moment" to transform Taiwan's economy and industries.

items.title: DTN Launches Ag Hub Platform for Supply-Demand Analysis and Farmer Engagement
items.description: Platform enhancements to Grain Intelligence, Grain Discovery and Farm Intelligence deliver connected insights across grain origination and agribusiness sales. The post DTN Launches Ag Hub Platform for Supply-Demand Analysis and Farmer Engagement appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
DTN, the agricultural data and analytics company, has launched the Ag Hub platform to provide farmers and agribusinesses with comprehensive supply-demand analysis and engagement tools. The platform integrates three key components:

1. Grain Intelligence: Delivers real-time data and insights on grain markets, supply and demand, with forecasts and analysis.
2. Grain Discovery: Connects farmers with buyers, enabling direct sales and improved price discovery.
3. Farm Intelligence: Offers insights on farm-level economics, production data, and agronomic recommendations.

The Ag Hub platform aims to provide a connected view of the agricultural supply chain, allowing farmers to make more informed decisions. Key features include:
- Live market data and price forecasts
- Grain market supply and demand analysis
- Buyer-seller matching and price negotiation tools
- Farm-level production data and financial insights
- Agronomic recommendations based on field conditions

The launch of the Ag Hub is part of DTN's ongoing efforts to support farmers and agribusinesses with data-driven decision-making. The platform is now available to all DTN customers.

items.title: AgriLife Extension adds six new county agents across Texas
items.description: Agents provide county-level agriculture, natural resources, youth, family and community health programming The post AgriLife Extension adds six new county agents across Texas appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
The agents will provide county-level programming in agriculture, natural resources, youth development, family and community health.

The new agents are:

The agents have various educational backgrounds, from animal science to horticulture, and previous experience working with AgriLife Extension and other agricultural organizations. They aim to connect research-based knowledge with real-world applications, support producers and landowners, and provide meaningful education and outreach to local communities.

This expansion of the AgriLife Extension county agent network ensures residents across all 254 Texas counties have access to expert assistance tailored to their specific agricultural, natural resource, youth, and community needs.

items.title: All Day Ag Outlook Conference March 3 at the Beef House
items.description: The 36th annual All Day Ag Outlook will be held Tuesday, March 3, at the Beef House in Covington, Indiana. Join the WILLAg analysts and the farmdoc team for the day. We’ll cover the basics this year, including the markets, weather, weeds, trade, competition, land values, and crop insurance decisions. Click the registration link for complete details. Doors open at 7:30 a.m. central / 8:30 a.m. eastern and include both coffee and rolls in the morning and a Beef House lunch.…

items.title: 2026 Angus Foundation Scholarship applications open
items.description: The Angus Foundation is accepting applications for its 2026 scholarships supporting Angus youth in agriculture and related fields. The post 2026 Angus Foundation Scholarship applications open appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
The Angus Foundation has opened the application period for its 2026 scholarship program, continuing its commitment to supporting the education and leadership development of Angus youth. Students can apply for the Foundation's undergraduate, graduate, vocational or technical, and commercial cattlemen's scholarship programs until May 1, 2026.

Since 1998, the Angus Foundation has awarded over $5 million in scholarships to students pursuing degrees in agriculture, science, business, communications, veterinary medicine, trade programs, and other fields. In 2025, the Foundation awarded $393,000 in scholarships to 142 students.

The Angus Foundation offers multiple scholarship categories, including:
- Undergraduate and Graduate Angus Foundation Scholarships (over $190,000 awarded annually)
- Commercial Cattlemen Scholarship (five $1,500 scholarships for undergraduate students using Angus genetics)
- Vo-Tech Scholarship (new in 2026, for students pursuing vocational or technical education related to the beef industry)
- External scholarships administered by partner organizations

"Supporting youth in their education is an important part of the Foundation's mission," said Jaclyn Boester, Angus Foundation Executive Director. "Our scholarships are one of the most prominent and consistent ways our donors support Angus youth. They pave the way for a bright future for our industry by ensuring young people can reach their full potential."

items.title: National ag teacher shortage threatens growth of FFA programs
items.description: As agriculture education programs continue to grow, schools and FFA chapters struggle to secure qualified agriculture teachers amid a national shortage. The post National ag teacher shortage threatens growth of FFA programs appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
S. According to Dr. Travis Park, National FFA Advisor, the shortage is the greatest challenge facing FFA and agriculture education.

The shortage is primarily driven by rapid growth, with 150 new FFA chapters chartered annually and a 2% increase in teaching positions from 2023 to 2024. However, the shortage is not just from expansion - 107 teaching positions were lost and 58 programs closed in 2024 due to lack of teachers, low enrollment, and insufficient funding. 

Rachel Kinsaul, a Georgia agriculture teacher, says the biggest shortage is in new graduates entering the field. This leads to industry professionals filling positions through alternative certification programs, which can be challenging.

Experts cite factors like low teacher pay, high workload, and retirements as driving teachers out of the classroom. Agriculture teachers earn lower salaries compared to industry opportunities for their skillset.

The National FFA Foundation and National Association of Agricultural Educators have partnered to provide $8,000 per state to recruit future agriculture teachers. University programs are also expanding, but the shortage remains a major threat, especially in states like Georgia that rely heavily on agriculture.

Addressing the shortage requires investing in and supporting agriculture teachers, who play a critical role in cultivating the next generation for the industry.

items.title: R.D. Offutt Farms digs deeper into research with new potato farm
items.description: A new 90-acre Wadena County site will focus on innovation, sustainability and practical results for growers.
items.summary:
R.D. Offutt Farms is establishing a new 90-acre potato research farm in Wadena County, Minnesota. The goal is to advance sustainable agriculture practices through dedicated research trials. 

Key details:
- The research farm will allow RDO to control variables and get more precise, repeatable results compared to trials within commercial fields.
- Planned research focus areas include nutrient management, genetic research, irrigation, product trials, and technology innovation.
- The research aims to benefit local farmers by providing practical, actionable data they can apply on their own farms.
- Results will be shared through field days, publications, and summaries.
- RDO envisions the research farm as a model that could potentially be adapted for other crops or locations in the future.
- Land preparation for the new research farm will begin this spring, with the first trials expected to start in 2027.
- The project is led by Tom Ryan, president of R.D. Offutt Farms, a family-owned business that has conducted hundreds of field trials over the past 60+ years.

items.title: Bipartisan Bill Seeks to Advance Offshore U.S. Aquaculture
items.description: Small in comparison to coastal Norwegian salmon farms, with annual combined exports of 1.2 million tons, Blue Ocean Mariculture produces about 1,100 tons of fish annually in net pens submerged 30 to 130 feet under water. Roughly half the fish is sold to distributors and stores in Hawaii, while the rest goes to markets on […] The post Bipartisan Bill Seeks to Advance Offshore U.S. Aquaculture appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
Key points:

- Blue Ocean Mariculture, a Hawaii-based offshore aquaculture company, produces about 1,100 tons of fish annually, with half sold in Hawaii and the rest to other markets.
- This is small compared to Norway's coastal salmon farms, which have annual exports of 1.2 million tons.
- The bipartisan "Advancing the Quality and Understanding of American Aquaculture Act" (AQUAA Act) seeks to establish a federal regulatory framework for offshore aquaculture.
- The bill is sponsored by Senators Roger Wicker (R-MS) and Brian Schatz (D-HI).
- The goal is to streamline the permitting process and provide more regulatory certainty for offshore aquaculture operations.
- Proponents argue this will help the U.S. reduce its seafood trade deficit and increase domestic seafood production.
- Critics are concerned about potential environmental impacts and impacts on wild fisheries.
- The bill aims to balance economic and environmental interests around offshore aquaculture development.

items.title: Cargill to close Wisconsin beef plant, cut 221 jobs
items.description: Cargill said the move was made "to better align our portfolio with current customer demand and prioritize investments," and ground beef production will shift to its other North American facilities.
items.summary:
Cargill, a major U.S. agribusiness, will permanently close its beef processing facility in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, eliminating 221 jobs. The plant will stop production around mid-April and fully close around the end of May.

The closure is due to Cargill's efforts to "better align our portfolio with current customer demand and prioritize investments." Ground beef production will shift to Cargill's other North American facilities, with no impact on its consumer contracts.

The Milwaukee plant closure comes after rival meatpackers JBS and Tyson Foods announced they were shuttering beef plants late last year. Beef prices are hovering near record highs due to strong demand and reduced supply, as the U.S. cattle herd has dropped to the lowest level in nearly 75 years due to persistent drought and a halt on U.S. imports of Mexican cattle.

U.S. beef packers have been losing money as tight supplies of cattle have forced them to pay more for the livestock they slaughter and process. The closure of the Cargill plant in Milwaukee will further impact beef supply and processing capacity in the region.

items.title: Not the same old crap: The high-tech future of manure management
items.description: From GPS to variable-rate tech, discover how manure is becoming a precision-driven nutrient powerhouse. Join Ashland SWCD for a deep dive into modern application. The post Not the same old crap: The high-tech future of manure management appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
Key Highlights:

- Upcoming "Conservation Chat" event on February 17, 2026 at 6 PM in Greenwich, Ohio organized by Ashland Soil and Water Conservation District.

- Event focused on advancements in manure management technology, including GPS, digital scales, variable-rate application, and precision controls.

- Speakers include:
  - Glen Arnold, Ohio State University - Research on using liquid manure for forage crops and impact of equipment/practices
  - Tubeline Manufacturing - New manure spreader technologies like GPS and digital scales
  - Erica Notley, Ohio Department of Agriculture - Manure application regulations, nutrient management plans, winter application guidance

- Goal is to help farmers stay compliant, confident, and avoid trouble with manure management.

- Information on cost-share programs available, including USDA, NRCS, H2Ohio.

- Tickets are $5 per person or free for two if bringing a friend.

- Manure management has evolved from "get it out of the barn and hope for the best" to a precision, data-driven approach - "not the same old crap anymore."

items.title: When Ohio loved snow: The history of pioneer sleighing traditions
items.description: Before snowplows, Ohioans relished the snow. Explore the history of pioneer sleighing with history columnist Paul Locher, from foot warmers to sleigh bells and community caravans. The post When Ohio loved snow: The history of pioneer sleighing traditions appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
Towns owned snow rollers to compact snow on roads, facilitating sleighing and movement of agricultural equipment with runners. Sleighs ranged from simple work sleighs to fancy Albany and Portland cutters with decorative brass fittings and paint.

Sleighing required accessories like buggy robes (often made from animal hides), heavy gloves, and foot warmers (tin boxes with hot coals or stoneware with hot water). Snow knockers - blacksmith-made iron hammers - were used to remove ice and snow from horses' hooves. Sleigh bells alerted others to an approaching sleigh.

Sleighing also involved nighttime torchlight caravans to neighboring towns for parties around a bonfire, allowing residents to socialize and build community. This winter sleighing culture contrasts sharply with modern Ohioans' disdain for snow and investment in snow-fighting equipment.

items.title: USDA Debuts Plan to End ‚ÄòAgricultural Lawfare‚Äô
items.description: February 12, 2026 ‚Äì Agriculture Secretary Brooke Rollins on Wednesday announced a plan to address an issue the Trump administration is calling ‚Äúagricultural lawfare.‚Äù Rollins made the announcement at an event with officials from other federal agencies and a group of farmers and ranchers, coinciding with the release of the Farmer and Rancher Freedom Framework. […] The post USDA Debuts Plan to End ‚ÄòAgricultural Lawfare‚Äô appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
The USDA has announced a plan to address "agricultural lawfare", which refers to the use of lawsuits to disrupt agricultural operations. Agriculture Secretary Brooke Rollins unveiled the Farmer and Rancher Freedom Framework on February 12, 2026, aiming to protect farmers and ranchers from frivolous lawsuits.

The key elements of the plan include:
- Creating a legal defense fund to help farmers and ranchers fight lawsuits
- Establishing an "agricultural ombudsman" office to mediate disputes before they reach the courts
- Implementing a "loser pays" rule, where plaintiffs who lose lawsuits will be responsible for the defendant's legal fees

The plan was announced at an event with officials from other federal agencies and a group of farmers and ranchers. It is intended to provide farmers and ranchers with the legal support and protection they need to continue their operations without fear of costly and disruptive lawsuits.

The goal is to reduce the burden of "agricultural lawfare" on the farming community and ensure that farmers and ranchers can focus on food production without unnecessary legal challenges. This initiative is expected to have a positive impact on the agricultural sector by reducing legal costs and providing greater certainty for farmers and ranchers.

items.title: New Voices, New Leadership, and Policy Uncertainty Shape the Ag Retail Conversation
items.description: Amy Asmus weighs in on Nutrien leadership changes, dicamba uncertainty, and the ongoing E15 policy fight. The post New Voices, New Leadership, and Policy Uncertainty Shape the Ag Retail Conversation appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
Amy Asmus, a respected agronomist, has joined CropLife Retail Week as a co-host. Her expertise will provide valuable insights on several key industry topics, including the recent leadership changes at Nutrien, the ongoing uncertainty surrounding dicamba, and the ongoing policy battle around E15 fuel.

Nutrien, one of the largest agricultural retailers, has seen significant leadership changes, with the departure of CEO Chuck Magro in April 2021. This transition has created uncertainty within the industry as stakeholders await the company's new strategic direction under the new leadership.

The use of dicamba herbicides has also been a major point of discussion, with continued regulatory and legal challenges. Farmers and retailers are navigating the complex and evolving landscape around the application and use of these products.

Furthermore, the debate around the availability and use of E15 fuel, a higher ethanol blend, remains unresolved. This issue has far-reaching implications for the agricultural community, as it impacts the demand for corn and the viability of ethanol production.

Amy Asmus' involvement as a co-host of CropLife Retail Week will provide farmers and industry stakeholders with a seasoned perspective on these critical issues. Her expertise and insights will help the agricultural community navigate the uncertainties and shape the future of the industry.

items.title: The Power Players of Ag Retail: Inside the CropLife 100‚Äôs Largest Facility Networks
items.description: Discover how the top ag retailers built massive facility networks driving logistics, agronomy support, and service capacity ‚Äî then explore the slideshow of the top 11. The top 11 retailers have an average of 255 facilities each, with the largest having 571 locations across multiple states. These facility networks allow the top retailers to serve farmers more efficiently with increased storage, blending, and application capabilities. Experts highlight that the ability to rapidly deliver products and services to farmers is a key competitive advantage in today's agricultural marketplace.

The Agribusiness Report podcast discusses the following key points:

- Soybean prices have risen 8% over the past 3 months, reaching $15.50 per bushel. This is driven by strong global demand.
